newsitem.title: USA: U.S. sees France continuing in anti-Iraq coalition.
newsitem.headline: U.S. sees France continuing in anti-Iraq coalition.

text.p: Defence Secretary William Perry said on Wednesday he expects France to continue to participate in the allied coalition against Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein.

Asked if the allied coalition against Iraq was weakening, Perry said: "I am confident the coalition is not weakening. If anythiny I think the coalition is strengthening and I fully expect the French to continue participation." He spoke to reporters at a joint appearance with visiting British Defence Minister Michael Portillo.
France withheld support from President Bill Clinton's cruise missile raids on Iraq on Tuesday.

Paris also indicated it had not agreed in advance to Clinton's extension of the no-fly zone from the 32nd parallel to the 33rd parallel just south of Baghdad. The United States, Britain and France have policed the no-fly zone since a U.S.-led coalition drove Iraqi forces out of Kuwait in 1991.

Pentagon officials said earlier on Wednesday that French Mirage jets took part in the first day of patrols of the expanded no-fly exclusion zone in Iraq. But French government officials later said in Paris that the Mirages stayed below the 32nd parallel.
